user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of set_self_name:
```c
static void
set_self_name (int argc, char *const *argv)
{
  if ((argc >= 1) && (NULL != argv[0]))
  {
    const char *last_dir_sep;
    last_dir_sep = strrchr (argv[0], '/');
#ifdef _WIN32
    if (1)
    {
      const char *last_w32_dir_sep;
      last_w32_dir_sep = strrchr (argv[0], '\\');
      if ((NULL == last_dir_sep) ||
          ((NULL != last_w32_dir_sep) && (last_w32_dir_sep > last_dir_sep)))
        last_dir_sep = last_w32_dir_sep;
    }
#endif /* _WIN32 */
    if (NULL != last_dir_sep)
    {
      size_t name_len;
      name_len = strlen (last_dir_sep + 1);
      if ((0 != name_len) && ((sizeof(self_name) / sizeof(char)) > name_len))
      {
        strcpy (self_name, last_dir_sep + 1);
        return;
      }
    }
  }
  /* Set default name */
  strcpy (self_name, "perf_replies");
  return;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected fragments that may hide unreachable code or constant/compile-time dead code: the platform-guarded block (#ifdef _WIN32) and the inner `if (1)` (a constant conditional); the early-return path that copies the basename and returns; the default-copy at the end; and the key conditionals that determine those paths (argc/argv check, last_dir_sep null-check, and the name_len/size check). These are the places where code may be effectively unreachable depending on build configuration or constant conditions and should be investigated.

Other lines were not included because they are simple declarations or assignments that are executed on feasible control-flow paths (e.g. variable declarations, the call to strrchr for '/', the name_len = strlen(...) assignment). There is no immediate indication in the snippet that those statements are unreachable by construction — they lie on conditional paths guarded by the fragments already listed — so they do not need separate investigation for Rule 2.1 beyond the conditionals and preprocessor/constant-condition sites already reported.
